content.raw: By removing the gazebo messaging we should also be able to make this PR compatible with Gazebo <= 8.0 since we avoid the Param and Param\_V message types.
content.html: By removing the gazebo messaging we should also be able to make this PR compatible with Gazebo <= 8.0 since we avoid the Param and Param_V message types.

content.raw:
I did some scaling tests to evaluate the potential for scaling issues with the new implementation. There seems to be no functional difference between the current default \(no synchronization\) and implementation in this PR.

Here are the details…

**Setup**

Created two catkin workspaces

1. **vrx\_ws** Containing this `wave_visualization_refactor` branch
2. **vrx\_nosync\_ws** Containing the temporary `unsync_wave_visualization_compare` branch, which is essentially the default branch, but with some added world/launch files to allow for an apples-apples comparison.

Modified the `generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys` script to allow for automatically populating a model with surmark46104 markers \(the aX obstacles do not have a buoyancy plugin in the current default\). Run the script to generate the model files in both workspaces:

```
cd ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/scripts
./generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys --L 500 --a3 0 --a5 0 --a7 0 --surmark46104 0 | tee ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf | tee ~/vrx_nosync_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf 
```

**Execution**

Run this in each workspace sequentially: `roslaunch wave_gazebo ocean_world_buoys.launch`

Record the CPU and memory usage reported by `htop`

* Started with just an empty world - no WAM-V, no buoys
* Added WAM-V
* Then added buoys

**Results**

Tabulated results are below, but here are my takaways:

* Keep in mind that in the nosync \(default\) case the buoys have a buoyant force, but it is from a flat ocean - the waves to not affect the buoy.
* The implementation of this PR uses a very, very small amount of additional resources, effectively equivalent to the current default.
* The incremental resources required for buoyant models is very small.
* Simulating the WAM-V, with the sensors, is the demanding component.
* Scaling to 100 buoyant objects is reasonable for both implementations. Unsurprisingly scaling to 1000 buoyant objects is not reasonable.

    * This should be more than sufficient for VRX.
    

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3297527468-sync_scale_testing.png)
content.html:
I did some scaling tests to evaluate the potential for scaling issues with the new implementation. There seems to be no functional difference between the current default (no synchronization) and implementation in this PR.

Here are the details…

Setup

Created two catkin workspaces

  1. vrx_ws Containing this wave_visualization_refactor branch
  2. vrx_nosync_ws Containing the temporary unsync_wave_visualization_compare branch, which is essentially the default branch, but with some added world/launch files to allow for an apples-apples comparison.

Modified the generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys script to allow for automatically populating a model with surmark46104 markers (the aX obstacles do not have a buoyancy plugin in the current default). Run the script to generate the model files in both workspaces:

cd ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/scripts
./generate_avoid_obstacles_buoys --L 500 --a3 0 --a5 0 --a7 0 --surmark46104 0 | tee ~/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf | tee ~/vrx_nosync_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/models/robotx_2018_qualifying_avoid_obstacles_buoys/model.sdf

Execution

Run this in each workspace sequentially: roslaunch wave_gazebo ocean_world_buoys.launch

Record the CPU and memory usage reported by htop

  • Started with just an empty world - no WAM-V, no buoys
  • Added WAM-V
  • Then added buoys

Results

Tabulated results are below, but here are my takaways:

  • Keep in mind that in the nosync (default) case the buoys have a buoyant force, but it is from a flat ocean - the waves to not affect the buoy.
  • The implementation of this PR uses a very, very small amount of additional resources, effectively equivalent to the current default.
  • The incremental resources required for buoyant models is very small.
  • Simulating the WAM-V, with the sensors, is the demanding component.

  • Scaling to 100 buoyant objects is reasonable for both implementations. Unsurprisingly scaling to 1000 buoyant objects is not reasonable.

    • This should be more than sufficient for VRX.

content.raw: With [171bc81](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/171bc8161a38cda060d83058858c2404f3f44dd1?at=wave_visualization), used erb to generate the ocean\_waves/model.sdf so that wave parameters only need to be provided once.
content.html: With 171bc81, used erb to generate the ocean_waves/model.sdf so that wave parameters only need to be provided once.

content.raw: Added `wave_gazebo_plugins` package to the list of directories to be checked by the static analyzer. [4b560d3](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/4b560d36535770dd91f0063b1ac8b66f2e62cccd?at=wave_visualization)
content.html: Added wave_gazebo_plugins package to the list of directories to be checked by the static analyzer. 4b560d3

content.raw: I just noticed that in `default`, the WAM-V is affected by the wind but in this branch the WAM-V seems not affected. Is it expected?
content.html: I just noticed that in default, the WAM-V is affected by the wind but in this branch the WAM-V seems not affected. Is it expected?

content.raw: Yes - the wind plugin is still active, the velocity is just set to zero.  I think the default should be for no wind.
content.html: Yes - the wind plugin is still active, the velocity is just set to zero. I think the default should be for no wind.

content.raw: We talked about this in person but I leave it here in case @Rhys Mainwaring or @{557058:6c52d6e5-77e0-41a8-8b6e-cb9462f4d5f1} have suggestions. The texture of the water looks a bit choppy and I wonder if there’s some configuration or anything we could do to make it look smoother.
content.html: We talked about this in person but I leave it here in case @Rhys Mainwaring or @Brian Bingham have suggestions. The texture of the water looks a bit choppy and I wonder if there’s some configuration or anything we could do to make it look smoother.

content.raw: Good news! This issue is fixed in [0956465](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/0956465a786a8caa20cf99fc10fe6e0ecd1996d5?at=wave_visualization). The problem was the simulated time was updated very slow \(5  Hz\) because it was taken from the stats message. We can read the time directly from the `Scene` at a much higher frequency. As a bonus, we don’t need to process that extra callback and we don’t need the mutex. Thanks to @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} for the help debugging this issue!
content.html: Good news! This issue is fixed in 0956465. The problem was the simulated time was updated very slow (5 Hz) because it was taken from the stats message. We can read the time directly from the Scene at a much higher frequency. As a bonus, we don’t need to process that extra callback and we don’t need the mutex. Thanks to @Ian Chen for the help debugging this issue!

content.raw: Fantastic - it looks much, much better.
Should the waves affect the docks? I see the effect on the WAM-V and buoys but not on the docks.
content.html: Should the waves affect the docks? I see the effect on the WAM-V and buoys but not on the docks.

content.raw: We have not \(yet\) added the buoyancy plugin to the dock block models.
content.html: We have not (yet) added the buoyancy plugin to the dock block models.

content.raw: I did a manual run through the navigation course for a couple wave settings within the envelope using all supported Docker builds \(Gz7, Gz9, with and without Nvidia support\).  As far as I can tell everything seems to be working as expected.  As a side note, RTF on the non-Nvidia version falls to about the .45-.6 range, but is still fairly usable.
content.html: I did a manual run through the navigation course for a couple wave settings within the envelope using all supported Docker builds (Gz7, Gz9, with and without Nvidia support). As far as I can tell everything seems to be working as expected. As a side note, RTF on the non-Nvidia version falls to about the .45-.6 range, but is still fairly usable.

content.raw: All looks good to me. Should we merge, and then, try the `wave_visualization` branch?
content.html: All looks good to me. Should we merge, and then, try the wave_visualization branch?
